grounding: I describe my career journey from a young girl in Cameroon, West Africa, to a trailblazing geophysicist to my current role as dean. I chronicle my time as a student, the transition to being an early career faculty, launching my research career, and ultimately finding my way to administration. Along the way I helped pioneer biogeophysics as a subdiscipline in geophysics while simultaneously maintaining an international research program in continental rift tectonics. I also describe the many intersectionalities in my life including being the first Black woman in many spaces, being a champion for student success, developing a diverse talent pipeline by enhancing diversity in the geosciences, and navigating academic job searches as part of a dual-career couple. Finally, I acknowledge all those who helped shape my career including the many students I had the opportunity to mentor.
generated_text: This autobiographical exploration delves into the life and career of Estella Atekwana, a distinguished figure in the field of biogeophysics and continental rifts. Through a narrative that intertwines personal experiences with professional achievements, the text highlights Atekwana's contributions to understanding the Earth's subsurface processes and her role in advancing diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) within the geosciences. The account also sheds light on the challenges and strategies associated with fostering student success in STEM fields, as well as navigating the complexities of being part of a dual-career couple in academia. This autobiography not only serves as a testament to Atekwana's resilience and dedication but also offers insights into the broader implications of her work for the scientific community and society at large.
